Supply Side—Failure of Government Housing Policies
With a rising housing demand, the government did not put much effort on raising supply. 22,000 new private flats per annum would be required during 2011-2021, according to the study of Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors. However, the average number new flats are 13,357, which was only 60% of the predicted demand. A severe shortage occurred and pushed up the property prices. The following policies failures are the reasons.

Land Application List System imposed tight constraints on land supply. It is a “developer-led” auction; if a developer submission price of land meets 80% of the undisclosed price set by the government, a public auction was triggered. After 1997 Financial Crisis, Hong Kong property market was declining. To avoid over-supply, the government replaced the conventional Regular Land Auctions to the System during 2004-2010. The land became extremely scarce; limited land sold equals to limited housing units. Even with irregular land auction adopted after 2010, the housing supply could not be increased instantly as time lag of construction exists.

Revoke of Home Ownership Scheme(HOS) exacerbated housing shortage. During 2002-2010, the government stopped construction of HOS. HOS supply decreased from a peak of 25,000 units in 2001 to 0 unit during 2011 to 2015. During the economic downturn, the public could afford the private units, but not in a booming market. More once HOS eligible buyers go to the private market and increased housing demands and prices.

Slow progress on urban renewal helps little on the housing supply. In 2003, 390 units were demolished for redevelopment. In 2013, 1,800 residential units were expected to provide by Urban Renewal Authority, the major urban renewal developer. The situation seemed improved, but it was still less than 10% of the goal of 22,000. Worst of all, the existing rate of renewal cannot catch up the speed of urban decaying. In 2040, there will be 24,000 buildings aged 50 years or above and 900 buildings per annum should be redeveloped; the current rate of renewal is 250 buildings per annum.

With a rising housing demand, the government did not put much effort on raising supply.

如果用prepositional phrase:
(1)
With the rising housing demand,
With the housing demand constantly driven by + n

(2) main clause:
the government has yet to implement drastic measures in regulating property prices.

如果用subordinate clause:
(1)
As the demand for housing is constantly growing,
(2) main clause:
the government has done practically nothing other than paying lip service in suppressing property prices.

如果用and 駁兩句clauses:
The housing demand has been growing and yet the government is doing little to suppress property prices.

你寫果句用錯article (should be “the” instead of “a”), 其次無帶出prep phrase 同Main clause 既contrast. 上面都用左唔同既文法同生字去寫同一句子，你可以參考下

有無聽過 George Orwell 的 Politics and English？我好支持佢的寫文理念

Never use a metaphor, simile, or other figure of speech which you are used to seeing in print. (Examples which Orwell gave included "ring the changes", "Achilles' heel", "swan song", and "hotbed". He described these as "dying metaphors", and argued that these phrases were used without knowing what was truly being said. Furthermore, he said that using metaphors of this kind made the original meaning of the phrases meaningless, because those who used these phrases did not know their original meaning. Orwell wrote that "some metaphors now current have been twisted out of their original meaning without those who use them even being aware of the fact".)
Never use a long word where a short one will do.
If it is possible to cut a word out, always cut it out.
Never use the passive where you can use the active.
Never use a foreign phrase, a scientific word, or a jargon word if you can think of an everyday English equivalent.
Break any of these rules sooner than say anything outright barbarous.
